cnzliH3maquUH1gM9-0j_Q.text: Less than average food with extreme rude attitude. Restaurant was about 80 pct full but 3 of us were made to wait. We were not allowed to take tables meant for 4-5 people.

mxa1nHqgQKRS8ONxIoJPMg.text: Incredible wonton mee! I was here two years ago and loved it. I visited it again on this trip and loved it again. Their food is very consistent. Flavorful soup, perfect wontons, the noodle has the perfect amount of oil and consistency, and barbecued pork is soft. We also ordered sides of steamed and fried wontons. They were also extraordinary. Little pouches of deliciousness! Highly recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore

NlHwOSHg9WICWL2wFDRHJw.text: Very solid wonton noodle house. It's famous in Singapore, and I was taken here by a local friend.We went at 1pm on a weekday and it was quite busy, both inside, and out (lots of people came for takeaway), so I can only imagine what a weekend would be like. Very fast service, friendly and busy staff bustling around getting the job done, adds to the atmosphere.They only do the wanton noodles, no other dishes (the menu is a single page order form that you fill out and take up and pay) so it's a testament to their longevity. The sauce is quite hot, but I'd still recommend a good glug of it mixed in with your noodles to give it some kick. The boiled wontons were great, whilst the fried ones and the char siew were nothing special. We had the extra greens which were also good.I'd definitely eat here again and would suggest getting the large portion (it's only an extra $1) if you are feeling hungry.

photos.caption: Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore. The Wanton Mee Noodle Feast, Eng's
Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore. Lime Juice, Eng's
Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore. The Super Hot Chilli Sauce, Eng's

1T7XW0eFVHbvnjccYnK_wg.text: They are back up again but it is real or fake??!!!  Man...looks like another war at work just like Laksa & Mee Pok at east cost as there is another starting right across.  Glad to say taste still same but curiosity will still bring me to the opponent across soon.

sw0uhYWdEy4nxh1pUDkP4g.text: Came here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon, and $20 got us veggies, fried wontons, two cups of barley water, two bowls of noodles, and clear soup. Very affordable, but taste-wise, nothing special. The wontons were okay, but it is hard not to like deep fried anything.The noodles, you adjust the seasoning (I mean HOT sauce) yourself, and add as much pork lard as you like. The pork lard is the saving grace of the noodles, because every mouthful was a pork lard and noodle salad party. Hot sauce... eh it was soso. In the end the noodles just tasted... HOT. No added dimension whatsoever, with some not-amazing char siew.

photos.caption: Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore

aG4ZOQRBq5Y_O5-ytFLjrQ.text: Custom made noodles tossed in pork lard, with a killer hot sauce.This place has come a long way from a cart at the intersection of Everitt and Duku Road, to a stall at Dunman Food Center, and now a shophouse along Tanjong Katong Road.I'll attempt to explain the polar reviews. It really depends on what you look for in your wonton noodles. Some people like the noodles, the roast pork (char siew), or the dumplings (wontons). Unfortunately, I haven't found a place that all aspects of this Cantonese dish right. Singapore-style wonton noodles also differ a bit from HK-style wonton noodles in terms of the sauce. At this place, it's only the noodles that are good. The noodles are different from the regular ones, and are factory-made to Eng's specifications. They are cooked springy and al dente, and firm to the bite, tossed in a generous amount of pork lard.The dumplings are also pretty good, with a generous filling and especially when they are deep fried. For those who like a soy sauce or ketchup concoction to go with their noodles, Eng's only provides a bottle of burning hot capsaicin-overload chilli sauce to go with the noodles. The roast pork (char siew) is generally dry and nothing to shout about. So if you're not a fan of their hot sauce, you'd find the noodles rather plain and boring.I'm somewhere at a 3.5 rating for this place. It's not worth the travel halfway across Singapore to get yourself here to try the noodles, but it is a recommended stop if you happen to be around the area. Again, the usual disclaimers apply.

OLTS3x3Ohcqv0Jj9DlpZLA.text: How nice it would be if there are more of such eateries focusing on just a few key and related food items. The menu is simple here you only have to choose either dry or soup version, and then there are only 3 side dishes and 3 homemade juices if you would like to order. All excellent quality and taste :-)

photos.caption: Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore

sr2h0YVSLVpbrgoIPfyD8w.text: I had the wonton mee and fried wonton. The dish is pretty tasteless and oily. I am used to either having a soy sauce based or tomato sauce based wonton mee but this dish is mostly oil based. There is a hot sauce that can be added for taste but it just made the noodles more spicy not any more tasty. The noodles are nicely cooked - right texture but the wonton was a miss for me. The wonton filling left me craving for more. The fried wonton is meh too. Nothing very special here.

photos.caption: Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore

9WzCVr-kG1avkjFvaGnJoA.text: This is definitely my favorite place for wanton mee in Singapore. Simple menu as they only specialize in this one dish and you can add a couple sides of vegetables and deep fried wantons. I personally prefer the dry version since I'm a slow eater and if it's in soup then the noodles just get soggy. The fresh noodles are nice and chewy and have a slight curl to them which is perfect for the sauce to grab onto. Make sure you give the noodles a quick toss when you get it so it's evenly mixed or the sauce really just sits at the bottom of the bowl. Homemade hot sauce on the table is delicious but it is indeed spicy so add with caution!Don't forget to serve yourself some pickled jalepenos and fried lard as they compliment the dish perfectly. Oh, and get the large!

A1C7ROzHls7pWAyuMD20TQ.text: There must be a reason why my colleagues would rile up the whole team, book cabs and ferry everyone all the way to tanjong katong for lunch... It's that good.For the newly initiated, the wanton mee is chewy and the gravy is just right. To add on to the feast, don't forget to order an extra plate of fried wanton to share! For the lovers of spiciness, the chilli, I hear is superbly hot. Too bad the tender tongue of mine is not qualified to try its wrath since I don't take pleasure in spicy food.Still, I Can't wait for the next round of Eng's wanton mee!

photos.caption: Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore. Beware of super hot chilli. =P

vkaLBJpcyX7brNHiiTyEiQ.text: After reading the reviews here, I'm honestly not sure why they revolve around the staff being less than super friendly. I mean, are you here for good service or good food? If you want top notch service, you won't get it from a place that charges $4-5 per bowl, realistically speaking. You pompous fools.Aside from that, I personally think this is one of the best wanton mee places in Singapore. The noodles are springy and never overcooked, and the char siew is tasty as well. I focus mostly on the noodle texture and overall flavor, and the entire dish is as savory as it can get. I know that it is not tomato / chili-based, but whatever they put into the oil mix is highly addictive to my palate. Definitely a favorite of mine, and will be back for more soon.

tuUvlmpvByeaYeSDPEZfmw.text: This place is awesome. Eng can teach a MBA class on how to run a successful restaurant business: simple menu, excellent food and consistency. Wanton Mee is second to none. Don't be a coward, use the chili sauce.

rHN60B1u3Me1FAECfJbteQ.text: Together with with 4 flavorful dumplings, the amount of noodles is pretty filling at $4. While some stalls are better at certain ingredients, say the char siew or noodles, Eng's version pays details to everything.No dark or light soy sauce like Kok Kee, the version here looks just as white as the one from Nam Seng. However, all is not lost. The pork lard that is tossed with the firm egg noodles not only prevent then from clumping and injects another dimension of fragrance. The charsiew have great caramelization with bits of fats. And the super spicy chilli lives up to its name as it is spicy, but in a different way. Because it is purely blended chilli, it tastes bitter. I did not really enjoyed it because it was not appetizing enough like Sambal chilli nor will it make you blow your nose or cause watery eyes like chilli padi. The noodles are simply good without the chilli sauce but no one would stop you from dousing it liberally into the noodles, turning the dish into a sea of orangey yellow (compare this and the top picture). The sauce is definitely bearable for chilli-takers, but I find that the bitterness (not spiciness) robs the original taste of wanton mee when squeezed in excess. We ordered extra wantons to share even though they were the same as those in the noodles. The pinkish pork filling were chewy and meaty.    I am glad that this wanton mee legend has continued in this era. If you haven't try it yet, please do.   It is something worth traveling all the way for, over and over again. A taste to remember

gvnW_3nMASAtAoYD1R_DiQ.text: It is ok la. This is Singapore style wanton noodles, which is so much better than HK style one if done right. I think many people likes it for nostalgic reasons, but my last visit two weeks ago didn't leave much impression. The noodles were not as tasty or flavorful as before and was even a little too starchy.. I think Kok Kee at Lavendar Food Square has this place beaten.

w1sLzU-fjpvuwlQTxyUg1A.text: This stuff has knocked Fei Fei right off as my go to place for Wanton Mee! Noodles are perfectly al dente, wanton is delicious (albeit slightly small for my liking). I am almost in two minds of posting this online in fear  of attracting the crowds.

OtGJyPiZHdX0lX5DaMn6Xg.text: A local foodie friend recommended this place. Clean and bright for a neighborhood eatery (be forewarned: no AC). Ordering was easy and the food came fast. We ordered the boiled wanton in broth, which was delicious. The wanton were bite-size and tender. The noodles came without broth and were good. While definitely a notch above the average "wanton noodles" at hawker centers, the fare didn't seem outstanding. Expensive for what we got.

Af6uojGGIGeZj9P5awvOtg.text: You get the traditional wanton mee here with chilli that packs a strong kick!The wantons here are not too salty and tiny, and come with very smooth skin that just glides in your mouth. The noodles are very springy or QQ and are cooked just right. Portions are pretty decent, and the char siew that comes with it is pretty okay. It complements the dish instead of out shining it.

OC2qBm6azbfcwA-eN9EhYA.text: It has been a long time since I last had wanton mee, and I wanted to seek out the best rated wanton mee stall that I have never tried. I obtained the name of this wanton mee stall and decided to journey to the east to see if the claims that this is one of Singapore's best wanton mee stalls is true. Turns out that it is somewhat true, although to be honest I have had comparable wanton mee elsewhere as well.First of all, do note that the chili sauce here seemed to be significantly more spicy than the chili sauce that I have had at other wanton mee stalls. The chili sauce here honestly made me break out a sweat, and I have not had that experience in some time. So be aware.The noodles itself was springy and had a distinct egg taste that I really enjoyed. The dumplings here are also tender and fresh, and very flavorful. The char siew was quite normal. Overall, an excellent plate of wanton mee, but be prepared for a long wait if you are here during meal times.I would easily rate the wanton mee here among the top 5 in Singapore.

photos.caption: Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Eng's Noodle House - Singapore, Singapore

BIGNUG7anRT4xYtSl2AHtw.text: THE CHILLI SO HOT.If you havent already eaten there before, be warned. For (most) Singaporeans, our chilli tolerance isnt too shabby, but this one is so potent, only the bravest will ask for extra chilli. Nothing said about surviving the aftermath. Even though the chilli these days isnt as hot as the original, I'm pretty sure it'll bring out a few drops of sweat while eating.But there is hope for the non-chilli eaters. The sauce comes in a squeeze bottle, so only you can determine how much pain (or gain) you want to put yourself through.Chilli aside, the noodles are great. They're springy with abit of bite and the wantons are really tasty. I like how the sauce combines so well with the noodles and dumplings, so on days when I dont have the courage to tackle the chilli, I can still enjoy a great bowl of wanton noodles.

Uokav6EuUFi6W2xzVulp5A.text: Not much taste in the noodle. The wanton has more skin than meat. The fried wantons are fresh, I would skip the boiled ones. Soup is good with strong anchovies taste. Will I go again? Unlikely, it is too easy to find better ones in this vacinity.

Br9_R4kCUXarGec64PRTcw.text: I live nearby and this wanton mee stall has been a lifesaver! its affordable, tasty, filling and i pretty much could eat it every week! The noodles are fantastic: the springiest, freshest, tastiest wanton mee noodles you'll find anywhere! i believe they make their own noodles in house. Their wantons and char siew are pretty decent, not particularly awesome but they do give a lot. their wanton mee soup is to die for! i think they use ikan bilis in the stock as i saw a few crates of the stuff out back. oh, and the in house drinks are pretty decent! (barley and water chestnut are my faves)service is brisk- the place is always full but never crowded and i've never had to wait more than 5min for my food.most of my friends whom i recommend to come here have said its the best wanton mee in SG, although some would beg to disagree
